title: Salmon Challenges

spawn_cards.title: You’ve Reached Your Spawning Grounds!
spawn_cards.credit: Photograph by Ryan Hagerty, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service
spawn_cards.body: When ready to spawn, female salmon build a gravel nest called a redd. One or more male salmon join her and fertilize the eggs she lays. Eggs hatch after about sixty days and a small larva (alevin) is born. Alevins continue to develop within the nest until spring when they emerge from the gravel as fry.

spawn_cards.title: Rearing
spawn_cards.credit: Jumping Salmon Fry, July 2015 License, Source
spawn_cards.body: Only about 20 of 100 eggs laid by female salmon survive to become fry. Once they emerge from gravel the fry need to find a good habitat. Only about 10 out of every 100 fry find the water and food they need—the others do not survive.

spawn_cards.title: Into the Ocean
spawn_cards.credit: Elkhorn Slough Reserve, NOAA’s National Ocean Service, August 2013 Source
spawn_cards.body: Each species of salmon fry has its own unique habitat requirements. After a variable time in freshwater, juvenile salmon move into the open ocean to mature and eventually, return to the streams where they hatched. A new lifecycle repeats with the next generation.

death_cards.title: Your Salmon Died
death_cards.credit: Dead Salmon, Ethan Ableman August 2010 License,
death_cards.body: There are many forces that threaten salmon during their life’s journey. While some of the threats are from natural predators or poor conditions human activities are the primary threats to salmon survival.

death_cards.title: Threats to Salmon, Threats to People
death_cards.body: For Native Nations of the Pacific Northwest, salmon is more than just a healthy source of food: salmon are considered relatives. Consider how threats to salmon also threaten the lifeways, cultures, and identities of Native peoples.

intro_cards.title: Salmon Challenges
intro_cards.credit: Portland Zoo- Salmon Cycle, February, 2013 License,
intro_cards.body: Play and learn what it’s like to be a salmon. The life cycle of salmon is both amazing and difficult. They are an anadromous species. This means that they are born in freshwater and migrate downriver to the ocean where they live most of their adult life. To reproduce (spawn), salmon migrate back to the river they were born in, then swim upstream to the area of their birth where they spawn and die.

intro_cards.title: Salmon Challenges
intro_cards.credit: Coho spawning on the Salmon River, Bureau of Land Management, January 2015 License,
intro_cards.body: Salmon face many threats during their life’s journey. Some of the threats are from natural predators and conditions. However, it is human activities that create the primary threats to salmon survival. In 2014, 19 populations of wild salmon and steelhead were listed as threatened under the Endangered Species Act. Salmon have already become extinct in 40% of their historical range.

intro_cards.title: Salmon Challenges
intro_cards.credit: Makah Feast Day, Salmon Bake, ca. 1955 Source
intro_cards.body: Salmon have always been important to the Native people of the Pacific Northwest. More than just a healthy source of food, salmon are considered relatives, and are essential to the lifeways, cultures, and identities of Native peoples. The Native Nations of the northwest feel a responsibility to the endangered salmon and they work in many ways to protect and preserve their animal relatives.

intro_cards.title: Salmon Challenges
intro_cards.credit: Coho spawning on the Salmon River, Bureau of Land Management, January 2015 License, Source
intro_cards.body: The end of the salmon story has not yet been written. In spite of environmental deterioration, overfishing, and other serious conditions, salmon still return each year to their home rivers to complete their life cycle and to give birth to a new generation. In this game, you’ll learn about the many kinds of challenges that salmon face in those long journeys to survive.

cards.title: Temperature Increase
cards.body: Salmon like cold water and you’ve just reached an area with higher than normal water temperatures that are caused by global warming factors, such as greenhouse gasses and pollution.

cards.title: Temperature Increase
cards.heading: How do warmer water temperatures affect you?

quiz_options.result: Correct. Salmon have to swim further to look for cooler water which tires them out. Gain 1 fish.
Correct. Warmer water leads to an increase in diseases and death in salmon. Gain 1 fish.
Incorrect. Warmer water temperatures don’t make it impossible for salmon to spawn; they just make it harder. Lose 1 fish.

cards.title: Inlet/Estuary
cards.credit: By BlueCanoe (Own work) [CC BY-SA 3.0 Creative Commons or GFDL], via Wikimedia Commons
cards.body: You’ve just reached an estuary. This is an area of water where the saltwater of the ocean mingles with the freshwater of a river.

cards.title: Inlet/Estuary
cards.heading: Why do you like reaching the estuary?

quiz_options.result: Incorrect. No, the estuary is not where salmon spawn. Lose 1 fish.
Correct. This is nutrient-rich water with lots of salmon food and places to rest. Lose 1 fish.
Correct. This is a good transition zone where you can adapt from saltwater to freshwater. Gain 1 fish.

cards.title: Overfishing
cards.credit: License, Source
cards.body: Many people love to eat wild salmon and that means there is a lot of commercial fishing. That’s bad news for you because instead of making it to your spawning ground you will become somebody’s meal.

cards.title: Overfishing
cards.heading: How can you avoid being caught by the commercial fishers?

quiz_options.result: Incorrect. You’re a salmon; you can’t stop swimming and wait for the fishing fleet to pass. Lose 1 fish.
Incorrect. Hiding is not a good option. The nets are hard to see and avoid. Lose 1 fish.
Correct. Just keep swimming and hope that you avoid the fishing nets. Gain 1 fish.

cards.title: Freshwater
cards.credit: Photograph by Bureau of Land Management, August 2015 License, Source
cards.body: Salmon are born in the fresh cool water of streams and rivers. They migrate to the saltwater of the ocean and live their as adults. Eventually, they return to the same freshwaters they were born in to complete their life cycle and spawn.

cards.title: Freshwater
cards.heading: Why do you like migrating into the freshwater of a river?

quiz_options.result: Correct. You are getting closer to the waters where you were born and the area where you will spawn. Gain 1 fish.
Incorrect. You’re not at the location of your spawning grounds yet, but you’re getting closer. Lose 1 fish.
Incorrect. You still have a tiring and dangerous journey ahead of you in the river. No fish lost, no fish gained.

cards.title: Poor habitat
cards.credit: Photograph by KOMUNews, June 2010 License, Source
cards.body: You’ve reached an area where the river you’re swimming in passes through a city. Although cities are important places for human life, cities generate a lot of hazards that have an impact on the wellbeing of salmon.

cards.title: Poor habitat
cards.heading: Which of the following city hazards must you survive in order to keep going?

quiz_options.result: Correct. Some sewage treatment plants deposit human waste materials in rivers. Gain 1 fish.
Correct. City storm drains carry pollutants like motor oils and trash into rivers. Lose 1 fish.
Incorrect. Some sharks are saltwater predators, but they don’t follow salmon upriver. No fish lost, no fish gained.

cards.title: Overfishing
cards.credit: Salmon Fishing, Stave River, BC October 2010 License, Source
cards.body: You’ve just reached an area of the river where sport fishers like to try and catch salmon. Sport fishers don’t catch as many fish as commercial fishers do but when there are many fishers it has an impact on the salmon population.

cards.title: Overfishing
cards.heading: How will you get by the sport fishers?

quiz_options.result: Incorrect. Taking the bait is a bad idea. There is a good chance you will be hooked. Lose 1 fish.
Incorrect. The middle is no safer than other parts of the river. No fish lost, no fish gained.
Correct. You swim by lots of baited hooks, but you don’t go for them. You made it through. Gain 1 fish.

cards.title: Temperature Increase
cards.credit: Photograph by NPS/USBR/USGS Elwha Restoration Project Imagery, 2013 Source
cards.body: Here you are on a nice cool river and you feel the water getting warmer. That’s not supposed to happen. Salmon like cool clear water on their spawning journeys.

cards.title: Temperature Increase
cards.heading: What could be causing the river water temperature to rise?

quiz_options.result: Correct. Land was cleared to make a farm, including all the trees and shrubs that shaded the river. Gain 1 fish.
Incorrect. The sun is not hotter on this part of the river. It’s just that the land was cleared to make a farm and shade is gone. No fish lost, no fish gained.
Incorrect. A higher elevation does not mean warmer water temperatures. In fact, it’s usually the opposite. Lose 1 fish.

cards.title: Resting Area
cards.body: The salmon spawning journey contains many hazards and conditions that are dangerous, difficult, and tiring. However, there are some places along the river that allow them to rest and eat before continuing.

cards.title: Resting Area
cards.heading: What are the conditions that enable you to rest in this part of the river?

quiz_options.result: Incorrect. Water moves slower on flat terrain but its not a good resting area unless other conditions exist. No fish lost, no fish gained.
Correct. Bushes and trees along the river bank provide shade and keep deep pools cool. Gain 1 fish.
Incorrect. There is no such thing as an official salmon rest stop. Lose 1 fish.

cards.title: Dam
cards.credit: Photograph by Doug McMains, 2016
cards.body: You have reached a dam that was installed on this river to create hydroelectric power for the people who live and work in this region. While electric power is beneficial the dam creates a huge barrier that blocks salmon migration and spawning.

cards.title: Dam
cards.heading: How will you get past the dam?

quiz_options.result: Incorrect. Unfortunately, there is no other waterway around a dam. Lose 1 fish.
Correct. Fish ladders have been installed at many dams. They help some salmon continue their migration. Gain 1 fish.
Incorrect. Spawning now is not an option. You need to get upriver to the area where you were born. No fish lost, no fish gained.

cards.sub_title: You have reached a man-made solution
cards.title: Fish Ladder
cards.credit: Photograph by Janet Lindenmuth, July 2008 License, Source
cards.body: Fish ladders are constructed to help migrating fish get past dams. They are step-like structures with water cascading down them. This allows the fish to jump and swim from step to step, up and over the dam where they reach the reservoir on the other side.

cards.sub_title: You have reached a man-made solution
cards.title: Fish Ladder
cards.heading: What is your biggest challenge related to using a fish ladder?

quiz_options.result: Incorrect. Jumping and swimming to the top is tiring but it’s not the biggest challenge. No fish lost, no fish gained.
Incorrect. Low water levels can be a make it difficult but it’s not the biggest challenge. Lose 1 fish.
Correct. Just finding the ladder can be a major challenge. Many fish don’t. Gain 1 fish.

cards.title: Reservoir
cards.credit: Grand Coluee Dam and Franklin D. Roosevelt Lake (Grant and Okanogan Counties, Washington), 2014 License, Source
cards.body: You’ve reached a large body of water behind the dam. It is a lake (reservoir) that is created when a river is dammed. The water is deep and has little or no current. Reservoirs create additional problems for migrating salmon. Eventually, if they keep swimming, salmon will reach the river again.

cards.title: Reservoir
cards.heading: What is your biggest challenge in making your way out of the reservoir?

quiz_options.result: Correct. The size of a reservoir and the lack of the usual river current make it difficult for salmon to find their way out. Gain 1 fish.

quiz_options.options: Thinking this is the spawning ground
quiz_options.result: Incorrect. Salmon aren’t fooled into thinking a reservoir is their spawning ground. No fish lost, no fish gained.

quiz_options.options: Being caught by a sport fisher
quiz_options.result: Incorrect. Salmon are at risk of being caught by a sport fisher but it’s not the greatest challenge. Lose 1 fish.

cards.title: Poor Habitat
cards.credit: Clearcut, 2006 License, Source
cards.body: You’ve reached an area where there is a lot of logging, An entire mountainside next to the river has been clearcut. This means that every single tree has been cut down to make lumber.

cards.title: Poor Habitat
cards.heading: How has clearcut logging altered your habitat?

quiz_options.result: Incorrect. Some loose sticks and branches might find their way into the river, but it’s not a big problem. No fish lost, no fish gained.
Correct. There are no trees and other plants to hold the mountain’s soil in place. Rain carries the soil into the river. Gain 1 fish.
Incorrect. It’s true the mountain is not as beautiful as it was when forested, but that’s not a problem for salmon. Lose 1 fish.

cards.title: Rest Area
cards.credit: Natural Logjam, Photograph by Sam Beebe, 2009 License,
cards.body: You’ve reached an area where there is an opportunity to rest. Log jams are formed when many fallen trees get stuck together in the river. They can occur naturally or can be man-made as an effort to restore salmon habitat.

cards.title: Rest Area
cards.heading: What is the benefit of a log jam to salmon?

quiz_options.result: Incorrect. Abundant sunlight would not be important to migrating salmon. Lose 1 fish.
Incorrect. Salmon like cold water. Lose 1 fish.
Correct. Log jams create deep pools of calm water that allow salmon to rest. Gain 1 fish.

cards.title: Trash Floating in the River
cards.credit: Photograph by U.S. Environmental Protection Agency
cards.body: Somebody had dumped a lot of trash in the river. Almost any kind of trash you can imagine can make its way into a river system. This pollution creates poor water quality and that means bad habitat for salmon.

cards.title: Trash Floating in the River
cards.credit: Photograph by U.S. Environmental Protection Agency
cards.body: Somebody had dumped a lot of trash in the river. Almost any kind of trash you can imagine can make its way into a river system. This pollution creates poor water quality and that means bad habitat for salmon.

cards.title: Man-made Dam
cards.credit: Photograph by Doug McMains, July 2016
cards.body: You’ve reached a dam that was created to generate hydroelectric power. The route to your spawning grounds is blocked.

cards.title: A dam with a fish ladder
cards.credit: Photograph by Portland Corps, July 2010 License, Source
cards.body: You’ve reached a dam that has a fish ladder built on the side for migrating fish. The dam is really big and the fish ladder is small. You get confused and are unable to find the fish ladder.

cards.title: Siltation
cards.credit: Photograph by U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service [Public domain], via Wikimedia Commons
cards.body: A lot of logging is going on in this area. All of the trees have been cut down and it creates soil erosion. The loose soil runs into the river when it rains. Some of it is suspended in the water making the water murky and unhealthy for fish. Some of the silt settles on the river bottom where it chokes the water plants and covers up the gravelly spawning grounds that salmon need.

cards.title: Siltation
cards.credit: Photograph by U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service [Public domain], via Wikimedia Commons
cards.body: A lot of logging is going on in this area. All of the trees have been cut down and it creates soil erosion. The loose soil runs into the river when it rains. Some of it is suspended in the water making the water murky and unhealthy for fish. Some of the silt settles on the river bottom where it chokes the water plants and covers up the gravelly spawning grounds that salmon need.

cards.title: Invasive species
cards.credit: Photograph by Kat Daned, August 6, 2008 License, Source
cards.body: Somebody has placed a non-native species of fish (pike) into the river for sport fishing. Although they are not in their native environment, pike thrive in this river and compete with the native species for resources. Pike are voracious and predatory and they like to eat other fish.

cards.title: Invasive species
cards.credit: Photograph by Kat Daned, August 6, 2008 License, Source
cards.body: Somebody has placed a non-native species of fish (pike) into the river for sport fishing. Although they are not in their native environment, pike thrive in this river and compete with the native species for resources. Pike are voracious and predatory and they like to eat other fish.

cards.title: Warmer water
cards.credit: Clearcut, April 2008 License, Source
cards.body: Trees and brush have been removed from the riverbank to make way for a new development. Salmon rely on trees and brush to keep the water nice and cool. The habitat is now compromised.

cards.title: Warmer water
cards.credit: Clearcut, April 2008 License, Source
cards.body: Trees and brush have been removed from the riverbank to make way for a new development. Salmon rely on trees and brush to keep the water nice and cool. The habitat is now compromised.

cards.title: No place to rest
cards.body: People have removed log jams from the river to allow safe passage for boats. While boats can now travel on the river without fear of running into a log jam, salmon have lost a crucial resting place along their difficult journey to spawn. Without the cool deep pools created by log jams, salmon must keep swimming even though they are fatigued.

cards.title: No place to rest
cards.body: People have removed log jams from the river to allow safe passage for boats. While boats can now travel on the river without fear of running into a log jam, salmon have lost a crucial resting place along their difficult journey to spawn. Without the cool deep pools created by log jams, salmon must keep swimming even though they are fatigued.

cards.title: Factory pollution
cards.credit: Photograph by Ingrid Taylar, February 2011 License, Source
cards.body: A nearby factory dumps its untreated wastewater into the river. This leaves dangerous and unhealthy deposits of chemicals and metals in the water and creates a polluted and unsafe habitat for salmon.

cards.title: Factory pollution
cards.credit: Photograph by Ingrid Taylar, February 2011 License, Source
cards.body: A nearby factory dumps its untreated wastewater into the river. This leaves dangerous and unhealthy deposits of chemicals and metals in the water and creates a polluted and unsafe habitat for salmon.

cards.title: City runoff
cards.credit: Photograph by KOMUNews, June 2010 License, Source
cards.body: The city has a drainage system that carries runoff from the streets into the river. When it rains everything that people dump into the streets can enter the storm drains and be carried into the river. Pollutants like motor oil, detergents, lawn fertilizers, and many kinds of trash create an unsafe and unhealthy habitat for salmon.

cards.title: City runoff
cards.credit: Photograph by KOMUNews, June 2010</br>https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.0/legalcode</br>https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.0/</br>https://www.flickr.com/photos/komunews/4683128554/in/album-72157624232753326/
cards.body: The city has a drainage system that carries runoff from the streets into the river. When it rains everything that people dump into the streets can enter the storm drains and be carried into the river. Pollutants like motor oil, detergents, lawn fertilizers, and many kinds of trash create an unsafe and unhealthy habitat for salmon.

cards.title: Agricultural pollution
cards.credit: Photograph by Oregon Department of Agriculture, April 2010 License, Source
cards.body: There is a beautiful fruit orchard near the river. Unfortunately, when it rains the water carries remnants of pesticides and fertilizers into the river. Such chemicals degrade are dangerous for fish and degrade the habitat making it even harder for salmon to survive their spawning migration.

cards.title: Commercial fishing
cards.credit: Fishing for Salmon, August 2013 License, Source
cards.body: People love to eat salmon and that means there is a lot of commercial fishing going on in many locations salmon pass through during the migrations that are part of their lifecycle. With many salmon endangered and threatened with extinction, commercial fishing represents a serious obstacle to salmon wellbeing.

cards.title: Sport fishers
cards.credit: Photograph by Tom Maliery, July 2010 License,
cards.body: Sport fishing is a recreational activity that many people around the world enjoy. It is also an enjoyable source of food. Salmon are a favorite species of sport fishers. With so many different kinds of forces at work against the salmon, sport fishing is viewed as yet another obstacle in their survival.

cards.title: Natural predator
cards.credit: Photograph by Shawn Kinkade, August 2010 License, Source
cards.body: Magnificent Orca whales swim the cold waters of the northern Pacific Ocean. They are a voracious natural predator of salmon. Pods of whales follow the migrating salmon and feast on them. Orcas are large animals weighing up to 12,000 pounds. One adult Orca can eat up to 375 pounds of food in one day. That’s a lot of salmon!

cards.title: Natural predator
cards.caption: Photograph by Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife, May 2016 License, Source
cards.body: Sea lions are a native species of the Pacific Northwest and natural predators that love to feast on salmon. As salmon populations diminish it affects the behaviors of other species. In recent years sea lions are extending their habitat range and becoming increasingly aggressive in their quest to find salmon to eat.

cards.title: Bears
cards.caption: Photograph by Christopher Strassler, July 2013 License, Source
cards.body: Bears usually live along the smaller rivers and streams that are the upper reaches of the salmon migration path. As a natural predator, bears know when salmon are on their spawning migrations in the rivers. They position themselves in the water where they can use their long sharp claws to snatch fish.

cards.title: Low water levels
cards.body: Low water levels can make the spawning migration even more difficult. This condition can be caused by many different factors. Extended periods of drought, or low rainfall and decreased winter snows create low water levels in rivers. The people who manage dams also have the ability to affect the water levels in rivers. Water is generally released from dams to keep an acceptable flow in the river. However, when drought conditions exist there may not be enough water in the reservoir to release into the river below. Low water levels can keep salmon from reaching their spawning grounds, which are often located in normally shallow waters. Lower levels also result in lower water temperatures, another hazard for salmon.

cards.title: Low water levels
cards.body: Low water levels can make the spawning migration even more difficult. This condition can be caused by many different factors. Extended periods of drought, or low rainfall and decreased winter snows create low water levels in rivers. The people who manage dams also have the ability to affect the water levels in rivers. Water is generally released from dams to keep an acceptable flow in the river. However, when drought conditions exist there may not be enough water in the reservoir to release into the river below. Low water levels can keep salmon from reaching their spawning grounds, which are often located in normally shallow waters. Lower levels also result in lower water temperatures, another hazard for salmon.

cards.title: Sustainable logging practiced here
cards.body: Timber companies that observe sustainable logging practices contribute to the wellbeing of salmon habitat. They remove only some of the trees from the ecologically fragile hillsides, leaving enough trees and undergrowth to keep the topsoil from eroding into the river. These practices help the water to stay clear and cool.

cards.title: Natural log jam
cards.credit: Photograph by Sam Beebe, 2009 License, Source
cards.body: Fallen trees find their way into rivers for many reasons. As they float downriver they sometimes get stuck on rocks, sandbars, or other natural features. When one tree gets stuck, other trees eventually float down and also get stuck behind. This mass of of stuck trees is known as a log jam. Log jams affect the river current, creating deep slow moving pools where salmon can rest and feed.

cards.title: Natural log jam
cards.credit: Photograph by Sam Beebe, 2009 License, Source
cards.body: Fallen trees find their way into rivers for many reasons. As they float downriver they sometimes get stuck on rocks, sandbars, or other natural features. When one tree gets stuck, other trees eventually float down and also get stuck behind. This mass of of stuck trees is known as a log jam. Log jams affect the river current, creating deep slow moving pools where salmon can rest and feed.

cards.title: Dam removed here
cards.body: In recent years some obsolete dams have been removed when they no longer serve a useful purpose or their environmental impact is too great. Many scientists and environmental groups believe this is beneficial for salmon recovery efforts but it is not a total solution. Habitat restoration and other activities need to occur to keep salmon populations thriving.

cards.sub_title: You’ve encountered a solution to a problem
cards.title: Fish ladder
cards.credit: Photograph by Janet Lindenmuth, July 2008 License, Source
cards.body: Fish ladders are constructed to solve the problem created when dams are built on rivers where fish migrate to spawn. This solution helps some fish get past the dam but it is not perfect. Dams are huge structures and fish ladders are relatively small. When migrating salmon arrive at dams they can become confused and it can be difficult for them to find the fish ladders.
cards.result: No fish lost, no fish gained

cards.title: Fishing restrictions in place
cards.body: Native Nations, state, and international governments all work together to support the fragile and challenged salmon population. Scientists monitor the numbers of salmon that return to spawn and this helps agencies determine how many and when fish can be caught in any given year. If restrictions were not imposed on salmon fishing, the species would not be able to survive.

cards.title: Fishing restrictions in place
cards.body: Native Nations, state, and international governments all work together to support the fragile and challenged salmon population. Scientists monitor the numbers of salmon that return to spawn and this helps agencies determine how many and when fish can be caught in any given year. If restrictions were not imposed on salmon fishing, the species would not be able to survive.

cards.title: Fishing restrictions in place
cards.body: Native Nations, state, and international governments all work together to support the fragile and challenged salmon population. Scientists monitor the numbers of salmon that return to spawn and this helps agencies determine how many and when fish can be caught in any given year. If restrictions were not imposed on salmon fishing, the species would not be able to survive.

cards.title: Riparian habitat restored
cards.credit: U.S. Coast Guard Base Kodiak crew opening access for salmon, May 2017. Photograph by Lisa Hupp. License, Source
cards.body: Local Native Nations and other partners have worked to restore damaged tree and plant habitat along streams and rivers. Keeping the habitat in good shape is especially important in the riparian zone—the area where the land and water meet. Trees, shrubs, and other kinds of plants in this zone keep the water cool and help to control soil erosion.

cards.title: Riparian habitat restored
cards.credit: U.S. Coast Guard Base Kodiak crew opening access for salmon, May 2017. Photograph by Lisa Hupp. License, Source
cards.body: Local Native Nations and other partners have worked to restore damaged tree and plant habitat along streams and rivers. Keeping the habitat in good shape is especially important in the riparian zone—the area where the land and water meet. Trees, shrubs, and other kinds of plants in this zone keep the water cool and help to control soil erosion.

cards.title: Sources of pollution managed
cards.body: Pollution has long been recognized as a threat to most animal species. Salmon suffer from a variety of pollution sources, including those generated in both urban and rural settings. However, salmon benefit from the laws and efforts of people to generate less pollution. Recycling, wastewater management, modern sewage treatment, and pesticide-free farming are just a few examples of the ways that pollution is being managed today in many locations that affect salmon.

cards.title: Sources of pollution managed
cards.body: Pollution has long been recognized as a threat to most animal species. Salmon suffer from a variety of pollution sources, including those generated in both urban and rural settings. However, salmon benefit from the laws and efforts of people to generate less pollution. Recycling, wastewater management, modern sewage treatment, and pesticide-free farming are just a few examples of the ways that pollution is being managed today in many locations that affect salmon.

cards.title: Sources of pollution managed
cards.body: Pollution has long been recognized as a threat to most animal species. Salmon suffer from a variety of pollution sources, including those generated in both urban and rural settings. However, salmon benefit from the laws and efforts of people to generate less pollution. Recycling, wastewater management, modern sewage treatment, and pesticide-free farming are just a few examples of the ways that pollution is being managed today in many locations that affect salmon.

credits: Created by the National Museum of the American Indian. Designed and developed by Interactive Mechanics.
